Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
Can anyone with git and github experience spot what I'm doing wrong here?

I'm trying to deploy to GitHub pages. It should be fairly standard stuff, and has always worked until I recently started collaborating with others in the same repository. Once I pulled in changes from a dev branch that had a few commits from another user, deploying to GitHub Pages stopped working.

I'm assuming that there's some environment variable somewhere that's giving git troubles, but I'm not sure where.

Here is the deploy.sh file that I run, and which is supposed to automate the entire GitHub pages creation process.

https://github.com/siddhartha-komodo/komodo-docs-vuepress/blob/master/deploy.sh

And here is a Gist with the terminal output when I run it.

https://gist.github.com/siddhartha-komodo/aa85ba91f177297cae97d82e585d86bf

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
I tried commenting out the `GIT_USER` stuff and returning it to `siddhartha-komodo`, my username.

This makes life difficult for gcharang, so we'll have to get it resolved, but it at least works for now.

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Thank you anyway.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content:
```To know if your project is in danger, run:

npm ls event-stream flatmap-stream
The bad actor has publishing rights to event-stream and flatmap-stream contains the malicious code (specifically flatmap-stream@0.1.1, but any future version can't be trusted).

```

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: if you have 6hrs and üçø , you can read: https://github.com/dominictarr/event-stream/issues/116

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: ok, this is pretty sneaky, and gave me a laugh: ```After he adds it at almost the exact same time the injection is added to flatmap-stream, he bumps the version and publishes. Literally the second commit (3 days later) after that he removes the injection and bumps a major version so he can clear the repo of having flatmap-stream but still have everyone (millions of weekly installs) using 3.x affected.```

Content: ```(Fun fact, when I go through all the passwords and credit card numbers I‚Äôve collected and bundle them up to be sold on the dark web, I have to do a search for my credit card numbers and usernames in case I‚Äôve captured myself. Isn‚Äôt that funny!)```

Content: "oh a fixed a typo" becomes a 300,000 line diff

Content: well, actually 300KB in one line, because minification

Content: it's like Freddy Kruger ran a daycare

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the Node + Javascript community as a whole values "moving fast" and "re-inventing the world slightly better every 6 months" to a frightening degree. It causes so much bloat and waste, it's very bizarre for Perl people that are usually worrying about wasting a few bytes

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i know that there are always issues with developers listing optional dependencies as non-optional

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the software has no way to know, it just installs a bajillion things

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and if you know you will never use random features, you can "cheat" and install less stuff. But also, nightmare errors might happen.... And I don't like dealing with nodejs backtraces.... ü§¢

Author: D.rabbani#9094
Content: hi i just got a querey about DPOW

Content: in case of DPOW is implemented will the blocks stop for certain time ?

Author: D.rabbani#9094

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: Unless there is an attack on the network, the presence of dPOW is barely noticeable. When a competing chain is introduced(that has been privately mined),  then the public chain is accepted by the network. This is the basics of dPOW. For a more general explanation, see:https://docs.komodoplatform.com/whitepaper/chapter3.html
